text:
It is a pioneering project
that inaugurates a new era,
where massive genetic data

will make progress
in global health.

With the support of AWS, we were able
to reduce a task that would have

taken 3,400 years on a 
normal computer
to just 30 hours.

I am Rayan Chikhi, Researcher 
at The Institut Pasteur
I lead a bioinformatics team,
and we study DNA using computers.

We analysed the entirety of sequenced
DNA present on Earth,

which corresponds to a volume of data 
1,000 times superior to what existed before.

The amount of genetic data
that we have analysed
in this project corresponds to about ten years
of videos stored on YouTube.

The Institut Pasteur is
a research institution
that has existed for 135 years,

and is one of the most 
renowned for biology research.
In fact, when you consider research in biology,

you often picture
researchers in white coats.
But that's not us.
Actually, we are computer scientists.
In fact, we conduct our research on computers.

There is a treasure trove
of genetic information

in databases that are never 
exploited, and the project

consists of analysing them in their entirety,
which has never been done before.
The database called SRA

contains the entire world's 
DNA, including human samples,

samples of bacteria, and even 
samples of penguins in Antarctica.

So the support of AWS
was key in this project.

We have discovered ten times 
more viruses than before,
thanks to massive cloud computing.
And so, in fact,

this project was funded by a European 
organisation called ERC

which funds basic research
for five years

and we received a significant
funding that allowed us

to perform these 
calculations using AWS.
We needed resources like the Cloud
to carry out those analyses.

So to host the data, 
we used a service from AWS
that is called the Registry of Open Data,

which allows data to be stored
publicly and free of charge,

which is very useful
for the scientific community.

We analysed 20 petabytes of data, 
which had never been done before.
These calculations were carried out

in just 30 hours using precisely 
2,180,000 processors at the same time,
which was a record for architecture used on AWS.

When I talk with my colleagues
who work with artificial intelligence,

they always tell me
that they are limited by the data

in text, in video and in particular
in genomics, in genetics.

So we, with this project,
we hope to expand
the volume of genetic data available

which will then allow training 
of new neural networks.
